posts.name:
Tomasz Boinski
Tomasz Boinski
posts.content:
𝐒𝐭𝐚𝐫𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐍𝐨𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐠: 𝐀 𝐒𝐦𝐚𝐫𝐭 𝐁𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐬𝐬 𝐒𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐠𝐲
In their book Bootstrapping Your Business, Gianforte and Gibson (2007) argue that starting a business with little to no money can actually be beneficial. This idea might seem counterintuitive, but there are several reasons why it works.

First, starting without waiting for funding means you can take action immediately. Instead of relying on potential investors to write you a check, you can begin building your business right away, with nothing holding you back.

Second, bootstrapping helps you learn faster. Most successful businesses thrive because entrepreneurs engage with suppliers, customers, and partners. Relying on cash can discourage you from seeking these valuable interactions, slowing your learning process.

Third, limited resources force you to avoid waste. With money in hand, it’s easy to spend on ideas that don’t pan out. But when funds are tight, you naturally focus on what truly matters.

Fourth, having little money limits your losses. Mistakes are inevitable in business, but without a large financial investment, those mistakes tend to be smaller and less damaging.

Fifth, starting without outside funding allows you to keep more equity in your business. When you take investment, you often give up ownership. By bootstrapping, you maintain control and maximize your eventual rewards.

Finally, constraints foster creativity. Studies show that working with limited resources pushes people to find innovative solutions. Without money to spend, you’re forced to think outside the box and come up with creative ways to succeed.

Most businesses around the world operate without external funding, focusing instead on managing risks and staying afloat. Bootstrapping encourages early feedback from customers, helping refine your idea and build valuable partnerships. It also forces you to test your idea in the real world quickly. If the business fails, you do so cheaply and without losing much control.

In the end, starting a venture with little or no capital may be one of the smartest moves an entrepreneur can make. It encourages learning, creativity, and efficiency, setting the stage for long-term success.




At, we champion entrepreneurs and innovators who embrace challenges and turn them into opportunities. Starting with nothing doesn’t mean you’re at a disadvantage—it means you’re building a business on a foundation of resilience, adaptability, and forward thinking.
posts.commentAdded: Love this perspective! Bootstrapping not only fosters creativity but also builds invaluable resilience. Its all about making the most of what youve got!

posts.name:
🏄‍♂️ Scott Leese
🏄‍♂️ Scott Leese
posts.content:
Average performers will always find reasons not to do things. This is never more obvious than looking at how sales leaders do their job.

A sales leaders job is not to sit around and audit opportunities and look busy.

A sales leaders job is to:

- train
- assist
- coach
- develop
- facilitate

If you are not improving your reps, and not making their jobs easier; you are failing as a sales leader.

I can hear weak sales leaders now saying: "you don't understand the pressure I'm under to deliver results. I don't have time to do that stuff."

Yes you do. You're letting the pressure get to you and you're scared.

Pressure comes when someone calls on you to perform a task for which you are unprepared. Paralyzing fear leads to reactive defensive action, the wrong kind.

But when you're prepared nothing a boss demands from you matters.

Fear that is converted into kinetic energy and execution...that is part of the fuel that drives the best leaders I know.

comments.commentText: spot on—real leaders turn pressure into progress and focus on building their team!

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Sales leadership is about empowering your team, not just hitting numbers. Preparation and coaching make all the difference!

posts.name:
Jon Leslie 🔵
Jon Leslie 🔵
posts.content:
When leading remote teams, there’s a heavy reliance on tools.

There’s simply no way around it.

However, HOW the tools are used can make or break remote organizations.

The most significant advantage of remote work is reduced distractions.

Despite this fact, some managers struggle with not being able to see teams working and continue to rely on office-based methods to lead and track progress toward goals.

This typically results in tool-based distractions:

️ Slack DM check-ins
️ “Quick” Slack Huddles
️ Daily Zoom status update meetings

Leaders need to stop trying to replicate the office.

It doesn’t work with remote & distributed teams and leads to dreaded RTOs.

Instead, trust the teams and visualize their work.

You can reduce reliance on Zoom and Slack with a good collaboration & planning tool.

Mapping team workflows to a modern collaboration tool helps the teams work together remotely and allows leaders to see progress without distracting the teams.

Team members want to know what fellow team members are working on…
 Look at the team board

Leaders need to see deliverable/goal progress…
 Look at the team board

One team held up by another team’s work…
 Look at the team board

No need to break focused work with distracting Zoom meetings and Slack DMs.

A good collaboration tool will also have built-in messaging, keeping the conversations asynchronous and relevant to the work and eliminating the frustration of having to check multiple tools for context.

Yes, tools are necessary for successful remote work, but use them to embrace remote work instead of negating its advantages.

-

 DM me if you want to see what I'm talking about in action

comments.commentText: We need successful remote leaders to speak up and share on LinkedIn. Show the working world how you succeed with remote—no more gatekeeping, please  Remote work needs you
Dan Salcius Yes, the bigger the remote-first org, the better. Remote at scale is truly impressive and absolutely not impossible.
Tools and frameworks need to scale.
comments.userName: Michael Illingworth BSc.(Hons)Computing, MAPM, MBCS, MIIM

comments.commentText: Michael Illingworth BSc.(Hons)Computing, MAPM, MBCS, MIIM Very true. The collaboration tool I'm most fond of does exactly that.

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Embracing the right tools can foster trust and enhance collaboration while minimizing distractions. Let’s lead with purpose!

posts.name:
Thomas Helfrich
Thomas Helfrich
posts.content:
"Build it and they will come? Nah, not in the real world." 

Rishi Khanna dropped this truth bomb on the latest episode of Never Been Promoted. Startups often waste time building solutions no one needs.

Why? Because they don’t stop to answer the basics:

 What problem am I solving?

 Who actually has this problem?

 Will they pay for the solution?

It’s like being a hammer searching for a nail—cool, but useless if there’s no demand.

As someone who’s been there (hello, lessons learned the hard way), I can’t emphasize enough: Talk to your customers. Validate the pain point. Make sure your solution hits home.

Don’t just build. SOLVE.

Catch the full conversation with Rishi Khanna! It's packed with insights for entrepreneurs navigating today’s market:
posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Understanding customer needs is crucial. Lets focus on solving real problems, not just building products. Great insights, Rishi!

posts.name:
Jeff Martin
Jeff Martin
posts.content:
Your mind is either your greatest weapon or your fastest killer.

The truth? Most of the stuff you’re stressing over right now is completely out of your control.

Someone else’s opinion of you? Out of your control.

The way a situation plays out? Out of your control.

Unexpected challenges that hit like a freight train? Guess what? Out of your control.

But how you respond? That’s where you have power. Your mindset is the game-changer. Stressing over what you can’t control is like pouring gasoline on a fire. It burns you out before you even get started.

The world will throw chaos at you—that’s a given. Your job? Stay focused. Stay sharp. Redirect that energy to the things you can control: your discipline, your effort, your attitude.

When you master your mind, you master the game.

Now go crush it.

comments.commentText: This is something we all need to be reminded of every now and then.
Staying positive and proactive is key in navigating whatever life throws at us

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Mastering our mindset is key to thriving amidst chaos. Lets focus on what we can control and elevate our game! 💪

posts.name:
West McDonald
West McDonald
posts.content:
#AI can transform how you and your people work, but you can do it really wrong too. So wrong people will shy away from it. GoWest.ai has seen businesses run into the same roadblocks over and over. Here are three common mistakes to watch out for:

1️⃣ "Free Tools Are Enough"
"ChatGPT is free. We let our team use it already."
Free tools are fine for personal use, but for businesses? Not so much. Without proper security or advanced features, they can actually hold you back. Investing in the right AI solution can save time, money, and headaches.
2️⃣ Throwing in the Towel Too Soon
"We tried AI. It didn’t work. We’ll wait until it’s ready."
AI isn’t magic—it’s a process. Early attempts might not go perfectly, but with the right training and tweaks, it can revolutionize how you work. The key is to stick with it and keep learning.
3️⃣ No Strategic Plan
Not treating AI like a big initiative.
If AI isn’t part of your overall strategy, it becomes just another tool collecting dust. The most successful companies have a clear roadmap for how AI fits into their goals.

AI doesn’t have to be overwhelming. It just takes focus and a bit of patience to see real results. What’s been your biggest AI challenge so far?
We're here when you're ready to talk.
posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Embracing AI with a strategic approach is key. Lets keep the conversation going on how to overcome these challenges! 🚀
